# ConstitutionsofWeb3

* * *

_This site presents preliminary analysis from the Constitutions of Web3 data set. If you belong to a DAO or Web3 community, [drop your constitution here](https://metagov.typeform.com/addconstitution)._

To the People of the Web:

After an unequivocal experience of the ineffectiveness of the subsisting institutions of the internet, you are called upon to create a new Constitution for a decentralized autonomous organization.

Decentralized autonomous organizations contain a particular promise: the ability to solve old coordination problems through ‚Äòsmart contracts' that encode constitutional rights. **Although smart contracts are promising new tools for governance, they alone cannot govern communities; traditional constitutions and declarations of rights are still crucial for good governance.**

Accordingly, we have created a number of materials to aid in your pursuit of a new Constitution. The first is an [analysis of DAO constitutions](https://constitutions.metagov.org/article). This article examines professed rights and values and places DAO constitutions in context with digital constitutions more broadly.

The second is a [data set of DAO constitutions](https://github.com/metagov/constitution-template/tree/main/constitutions). We expect the analysis and data set to be of interest to scholars and practitioners seeking a broader perspective on DAO constitutions.

The third is a [guide to creating constitutions](https://constitutions.metagov.org/guide). From our analyses of constitutions and interviews with constitution authors, we present recommendations for beginning to draft a constitution. We hope for this to be useful for organizations considering constitutions or in the early stages of drafting.

Alongside the guide is a [minimal constitutional template](https://constitutions.metagov.org/template). When combined with the guide and our [data set of constitutions](https://github.com/metagov/constitution-template/tree/main/constitutions), we expect this template to be helpful when at the earliest stages of constitution creation.

May the lessons of the past continue to guide the growth of the future.

[![Public Hearing on Zoning](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Screenshot-2025-09-05-at-12.31.42-PM.png)](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/public-hearing-on-zoning/)

## [Public Hearing on Zoning](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/public-hearing-on-zoning/)

Sep 5, 2025

This is a critical moment to make your voice heard and show your support. The SRD will be hosting a public hearing to discuss the proposed bylaw on Monday, September 8th @ 5pm at Manson‚Äôs Hall. We encourage you to attend and share your perspective.

[Learn More >>](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/public-hearing-on-zoning/)

[![Results of the Cortes Aquifer Study](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/jimmy-chang-NP8gd2KUnfw-unsplash-1080x675.jpg)](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/results-of-the-cortes-aquifer-study/)

## [Results of the Cortes Aquifer Study](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/results-of-the-cortes-aquifer-study/)

Sep 2, 2025

We are pleased to present the findings of the Cortes Island Aquifer Health Assessment, a study commissioned by the Cortes Housing Society to map and assess the health of our island aquifers. This report, made possible with funding from the Real Estate Foundation of BC, gives us the critical data needed to responsibly plan for the years ahead.

[Learn More >>](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/results-of-the-cortes-aquifer-study/)

[![Pictures from Natural Building Workshop & Open House](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/2dd4a34b-9ded-4827-a04d-2177315240af-1.jpeg)](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/pictures-from-natural-building-workshop-open-house/)

## [Pictures from Natural Building Workshop & Open House](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/pictures-from-natural-building-workshop-open-house/)

Jul 18, 2025

Thank you to all who attended our Natural Building Workshop and Rainbow Ridge Open House last weekend. With over 75 people stopping by to share their ideas and cheer us on, it was a wonderful event. With direction from Mark Lombard, volunteers built a chip slip wall to adorn our community building. Thank you for helping make our dreams a reality!

[Learn More >>](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/pictures-from-natural-building-workshop-open-house/)

[![New Design for Rainbow Ridge](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/Screenshot-2025-10-03-at-10.08.21-AM-1080x675.png)](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/new-design-for-rainbow-ridge/)

## [New Design for Rainbow Ridge](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/new-design-for-rainbow-ridge/)

Jul 10, 2025

After several design revisions, we‚Äôre excited to share the updated layout for our community development on Sunday, July 13th from 10 AM to noon at Rainbow Ridge.

[Learn More >>](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/new-design-for-rainbow-ridge/)

[See Older Posts](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/#)

[![Natural Building Workshop & Rainbow Ridge Open House](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/Slip-Chip-Workshop-Poster-400x250.jpg)](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/natural-building-workshop-rainbow-ridge-open-house/)

## [Natural Building Workshop & Rainbow Ridge Open House](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/natural-building-workshop-rainbow-ridge-open-house/)

Jul 2, 2025

We are hosting two upcoming events on the weekend of July 11th. The first is a 3 day workshop on chip slip natural building. There are opportunities to drop in for 3 hour sessions as well. Please email us to register.

[![Aquifer Project Update](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/Aquifer-for-Tideline-400x250.jpeg)](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/aquifer-project-update/)

## [Aquifer Project Update](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/aquifer-project-update/)

May 14, 2025

With clear skies and summer just around the corner, are you concerned about your well water supply and having enough water for crops and household needs? What can we do to protect groundwater sources on Cortes Island and ensure that development is sustainable over the long-term?

[![Seasonal Employee Housing](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/4a4c150d-f07d-2edb-9a73-2f1c2978320e-400x250.jpg)](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/seasonal-employee-housing/)

## [Seasonal Employee Housing](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/seasonal-employee-housing/)

Jun 4, 2025

As a part of our effort to support housing on Cortes, the Cortes Housing Society (CHS) is working to address the significant challenges that employers and employees face finding adequate housing in the summer. Seasonal housing challenges are impacting local organizations and business‚Äôs ability to retain existing employees and attract new seasonal workers during peak season.

[![Rainbow Ridge Update](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/2025_May_RR_Crew-400x250.jpg)](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/rainbow-ridge-update/)

## [Rainbow Ridge Update](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/rainbow-ridge-update/)

May 9, 2025

Things are moving ahead at Rainbow Ridge. The land is now cleared for 24 townhomes. Three logging truck loads will be locally milled into timber for our community building. Lower grade wood will provide firewood for islanders and donations to the school wetlands project.

[![Makerspace in Action](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/2025_coldframe-building-400x250.jpeg)](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/makerspace-in-action/)

## [Makerspace in Action](https://cortescommunityhousing.org/makerspace-in-action/)

May 30, 2025

The Cortes Community Health Association and the Cortes Housing Society have been working together this past month. # Socially Responsible Renewable Energy Development Short Course

Learn to design renewable energy projects that achieve stronger social and environmental outcomes while building lasting social licence.

SRRED offers flexible, online learning modules designed to equip participants with practical strategies for enhancing social and environmental outcomes in renewable energy projects.

This self-paced program allows learners to engage with diverse materials at their convenience, ensuring both an interactive and accessible educational experience.

[ENROL NOW](https://shortcourses.griffith.edu.au/courses/srred)

### Key course features

![](https://cpagency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/SRRED-course-online-modules-e1736404200896-768x489.png)

### Interactive Online Learning Modules

Accessible, engaging content with reflective activities, real-world case studies and insights from industry experts.

![Solar panels in field](https://cpagency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/IMG_1045.jpg)

### SRRED Exchange Community

Access to the online SRRED Exchange platform, a vibrant community of practice that enables sector collaboration and knowledge sharing, as well as live seminars featuring guest speakers.

![](https://cpagency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/digital_badge.png)

### Digital Badge

Delivered in partnership with Griffith University and accredited with a digital badge.

![](https://cpagency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/cpa_img_4-1-1536x749.jpg)

### Course overview

SRRED offers flexible, online learning modules designed to equip participants with practical strategies for enhancing social and environmental outcomes in renewable energy projects. This self-paced program allows learners to engage with diverse materials at their convenience, ensuring both an interactive and accessible educational experience.

Who is this course suited to?

This course is designed for renewable energy practitioners, advocates, and policymakers who are committed to ensuring that renewable energy projects deliver positive social, environmental, and economic outcomes. It is particularly relevant for professionals in executive leadership, project development, project management, and community engagement roles.

Whether you are working on large-scale renewable projects, shaping policy, or supporting communities through the energy transition, this course will equip you with the frameworks, tools, and case studies needed to navigate the complexities of socially responsible renewable energy development.

Course duration and delivery

This course is fully self-paced, allowing participants to complete the two online modules at their own convenience. There are no required live sessions ‚Äîonce both modules are successfully completed, including the associated workbook, participants will be eligible for a digital badge.

Participants should allow approximately **40hrs** to complete SRRED.

What are the course credentials?

Upon successful completion of the course, participants will receive a **digital badge** in Socially Responsible Renewable Energy Development from Griffith University.

What is the SRRED Exchange?

The SRRED Exchange platform is an ongoing, online community of practice that fosters collaboration, knowledge sharing, and peer learning. It will feature live sessions aligned with the two learning modules, connect participants taking the course, and provide a space for questions, discussion and interaction.

Pricing and discounts‚Äã

- **Full price**: $2,500 (incl. GST)
- **\*Community discount:** $2,000 (20% off ‚Äì for local government, NFPs, charities, and social enterprises)
- **Group discounts:** we‚Äôre offering group discounts for organisations wanting to enrol three or more people. [Reach out to discuss](http://srred@cpagency.org.au/).

\*If you‚Äôre eligible for the community discount, contact us to receive your discount code ‚Äì srred@cpagency.org.au

If price is a limiting factor for you or your organisation then please reach out to discuss.

## Course modules

This course is structured into two modules, covering:

Module 1: Community engagement

Effective community engagement is essential for the success of renewable energy projects. This module explores the foundations of social licence, the importance of understanding the social context, and the principles of meaningful engagement and participation. Participants will also learn strategies for deepening engagement with First Nations communities and how to develop and evaluate effective engagement plans. Through real-world examples and best-practice frameworks, this module equips practitioners with the skills to build trust, foster genuine collaboration, and navigate the complexities of community engagement in renewable energy development.

**Chapters include:**

- Chapter 1 ‚Äì Social licence
- Chapter 2 ‚Äì Understanding the social context
- Chapter 3 ‚Äì Principles of community engagement and participation
- Chapter 4 ‚Äì Deepening engagement with First Nations
- Chapter 5 ‚Äì Engagement planning and evaluation

Module 2: Creating Benefit

Renewable energy projects have the potential to deliver lasting benefits for communities.

This module explores different approaches to benefit sharing, ensuring that projects generate positive social and economic outcomes. Participants will examine co-design processes and governance structures, as well as co-investment and co-ownership models that enable greater community participation. The module also covers strategies for preparing communities for the energy transition, including employment and procurement opportunities, and affordable housing solutions to support the transition. Additionally, it addresses best practices for shared land use and biodiversity conservation.

By the end of this module, participants will have the tools to design projects that are both socially responsible and locally beneficial.

**Chapters include:**

Module 2 ‚Äì Creating benefit

- Chapter 1 ‚Äì Benefit sharing
- Chapter 2 ‚Äì Co-design and governance structures
- Chapter 3 ‚Äì Co-investment and co-ownership models
- Chapter 4 ‚Äì Preparing communities for the transition
- Chapter 5 ‚Äì Shared land use and biodiversity

### Course learning outcomes

After completing this course, you will:

- Understand social licence and engagement principles.
- Gain strategic knowledge of the social context of renewable energy projects.
- Develop effective community engagement plans and evaluation methods.
- Learn how to engage meaningfully with First Nations communities.
- Explore benefit-sharing concepts and options.
- Understand legal and financial models for co-investment and co-ownership.
- Learn to form partnerships for local economic development (e.g. procurement, employment and legacy initiatives).
- Acquire skills to manage tricky situations and handle complaints.

Understand opportunities and challenges for balancing nature conservation and renewable energy development.

[ENROL NOW](https://shortcourses.griffith.edu.au/courses/srred)

![A single wind turbine standing in a dry. arid, regional Australian landscape.](https://cpagency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/kshithij-chandrashekar-fgaqpNC9zas-unsplash-4-768x512.jpg)

## Course speakers

[![](https://cpagency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/Dr_Jarra_Hicks.jpg)](https://cpagency.org.au/person/dr-jarra-hicks/)

### [Dr Jarra Hicks](https://cpagency.org.au/person/dr-jarra-hicks/)

Jarra is a founding Director of Community Power Agency and a course convener of the SRRED course. With 15 years of experience in community energy across Australia and overseas, her expertise spans community engagement, business model design, facilitation, policy development and partnership building. In the SRRED course, Jarra explores key concepts of social licence and shares practical, experience-based strategies for planning and delivering effective community engagement.

[![](https://cpagency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/Elizabeth_Noble-1.jpg)](https://cpagency.org.au/person/elizabeth-noble/)

### [Elizabeth Noble](https://cpagency.org.au/person/elizabeth-noble/)

Elizabeth is a Director at Community Power Agency, with over 20 years‚Äô experience working at the intersection of environmental sustainability and community-centred change. She leads the coordination of the SRRED course, and brings strong expertise in community engagement, participatory planning, and energy equity.

[![](https://cpagency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/Kim-head-shot.jpeg)](https://cpagency.org.au/person/kim-mallee/)

### [Kim Mallee](https://cpagency.org.au/person/kim-mallee/)

Kim is a Director at Community Power Agency and a recognised expert in community engagement and benefit sharing. With over a decade of experience in local government and extensive work with state and federal agencies, Kim brings a deep understanding of the role of government in shaping equitable energy transitions. In the SRRED course, she shares insights on how policy can strengthen positive social outcomes, and offers practical strategies for building and maintaining social licence over the life of renewable energy projects.

[![](https://cpagency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/Heidi_McElnea-1.jpg)](https://cpagency.org.au/person/heidi-mcelnea/)

### [Heidi McElnea](https://cpagency.org.au/person/heidi-mcelnea/)

Heidi works on Kamilaroi country in the New England REZ as Community Power Agency's Regional Partnerships Coordinator. She specialises in shared land use, biodiversity, local procurement, and preparing communities for the renewable energy transition. With 25 years‚Äô experience in communications, engagement, and training, she brings a strong place-based lens to her work. In the SRRED course, Heidi shares insights on supporting communities to navigate change and maximise local benefits.

[![](https://cpagency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/Taryn-480x480-1.jpg)](https://au.linkedin.com/in/taryn-lane-18832a29)

### [Taryn Lane](https://au.linkedin.com/in/taryn-lane-18832a29)

Taryn has led Hepburn Energy Australia's first community-owned wind farm for 15 years and also works as a consultant. She was a Founding Director of RE-Alliance and currently serves on the board of the Smart Energy Council. She has delivered community ownership and co-investment models in Australian renewable energy projects. In the SRRED course, she shares deep insights into meaningful community participation, highlighting the opportunities and benefits of these models.

[![](https://cpagency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/ruby-heard_51663190921_o.jpg)](https://www.alingaenergy.com/about)

### [Ruby Heard](https://www.alingaenergy.com/about)

Ruby is a descendant of the Jaru people from the Eastern Kimberley region of Western Australia and an electrical engineer by training. She leads Alinga Energy Consulting, specialising in renewable energy and microgrid solutions. In the SRRED course, Ruby offers a First Nations perspective on social licence and shares practical guidance on how to foster deeper engagement with First Nations communities in the context of renewable energy development.

[![](https://cpagency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/susieburke-lowres-2022-1.jpg)](https://www.susieburke.com.au/)

### [Dr Susie Burke](https://www.susieburke.com.au/)

Dr Burke is a psychologist who specialises in climate change psychology and community wellbeing. In the SRRED course, she offers practical strategies for navigating complex conversations, addressing misinformation, and ensuring inclusive, respectful engagement. Dr Burke also shares tools for self-care and emotional resilience, supporting practitioners to sustain their wellbeing while working on challenging issues.

[![](https://cpagency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/240307_Bright_Photography_StrideRenewables_Finals_C_LR-13-1.jpg)](https://au.linkedin.com/in/lhosborne)

### [Luke Osborne](https://au.linkedin.com/in/lhosborne)

Luke is a partner at Stride Renewables with over two decades of experience in the energy sector. In the SRRED course, Luke brings a developer‚Äôs perspective on social licence, highlighting the importance of genuine community engagement and effective benefit-sharing strategies to build trust and long-term project success.

[![](https://cpagency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/NS-Geni.Energy-22-scaled.jpg)](https://www.geni.energy/about)

### [Sally Hunter](https://www.geni.energy/about)

Sally is the Founder and Managing Director of Geni.Energy, an advocacy and consultancy organisation dedicated to driving local jobs and investment from renewable energy in her hometown of Narrabri, in northwest New South Wales. In the SRRED course, Sally brings a community perspective on social licence, co-ownership models and effective community engagement.

[![](https://cpagency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/Headshot-of-Peter-Marriott.jpg)](https://au.linkedin.com/in/peter-marriott-0237b344)

### [Peter Marriott](https://au.linkedin.com/in/peter-marriott-0237b344)

Peter is the Founding Director of OSMI Australia. He has been working in wind farm development and asset management for over 20 years and brings the unique experience of also hosting an operating wind farm on his family‚Äôs property in South Gippsland. In the SRRED course, he shares a developer‚Äôs perspective on community co-investment models based on his experience on the Delburn Wind Farm near the Latrobe Valley in Victoria.

![](https://cpagency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/Tegan-Miller.jpg)

### Tegan Miller

Tegan works part-time at CitiPower, Powercor and United Energy and the First Nations Clean Energy Network, both roles allow her to understand First Peoples issues, barriers and solutions to accessing energy and owning and developing renewable energy projects. In the SRRED course, Tegan shares insights into the principle of Free, Prior and Informed Consent and its critical role in renewable energy projects involving First Nations communities. She also draws on international examples of Indigenous engagement, particularly from Canada, to broaden participants' understanding of best practices in this space.

[![](https://cpagency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/Andy-Bray-Re-Alliance.jpeg)](https://www.re-alliance.org.au/andrew_bray)

### [Andrew Bray](https://www.re-alliance.org.au/andrew_bray)

Andrew has served as the National Director of RE-Alliance since 2013, growing the organisation into a leading voice for regional communities in Australia‚Äôs energy transition. His work focuses on ensuring that communities are heard and benefit from the shift to renewable energy, particularly in areas such as transmission, community benefit sharing and mitigating local impacts. In the SRRED course, Andrew explores different models of community benefit funds and discusses the role of Local Energy Hubs in supporting communities in the shift to renewables.

Mint

For all of our excitement about the ways that DAOs could usher in a revolution of collective action, we should remember: they wouldn‚Äôt be the first one, and they won‚Äôt be the last.

Our current world is designed primarily around large centralized structures like national governments, universities, and corporations. But this hasn‚Äôt always been the case‚Äî [cycles of decentralization and centralization](https://creators.mirror.xyz/s9h4_PQAcJyqgC0rnsWjw9geU2wJs-IBPXIzHhgi-P8) define the ebb and flow of major periods of human history.

We seem to be in a late-stage period of the modern era, where centralized institutions are failing. So it‚Äôs natural to run in the other direction, to swing the pendulum toward decentralized maximalism. Maximalism is the strategy of a cancer cell. Successful complex systems are diverse, permeable, and inherently pluralistic.

If we‚Äôre going to run screaming from centralization, we need to have a sense of where we are running towards as well as what we are running from. Movements focused on abandoning centralized structures without suitable replacements tend to end in [apathetic collective action failure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arab_Spring), or worse, [mob rule](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reign_of_Terror). If we are to avoid the proverbial guillotine, we should learn what has worked and failed in other decentralized organizations. We need to ask ourselves:

> ### In what ways can decentralized organizations outcompete more centralized ones?

Ideologies don‚Äôt win by claiming superiority‚Äîthey win by demonstrating that they can solve real problems more effectively than the alternatives. So it‚Äôs worth deeply understanding what has actually made decentralized organizations better (and worse) than the available alternatives.

## Principles of successful decentralized organizations

Here are four very different kinds of organizations that have something to teach us about building DAOs:

- [Valve](https://www.valvesoftware.com/en/), the company behind Steam
- the [US Marine Corps](https://www.marines.com/)
- intentional [co-living](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Co-living) communities
- [Amazon](https://www.amazon.com/)

Each of these organizations operates in decentralized ways that result in better outcomes than more centralized peers. They have created flexible, adaptable, creative, and capable evolutionary systems that can outperform more rigid hierarchies in rapidly changing environments.

This wide range of organizational types shows the different ways that decentralization can manifest as a strength. By looking at the commonalities in their principles, we can understand what makes decentralized organizations successful. Here are a some of the principles they all have in common:

1. Recruit the best people
2. Help members self-organize
3. Empower mission-driven leaders
4. Have a bias towards action
5. Play infinite games

Note that none of these principles are about decentralization absolutism. They are about finding the right balance between decentralized self-organization and flexible leadership structures that create Schelling points for collective action. Let‚Äôs explore each one in a bit more detail.

### 1 - Recruit the best people

There‚Äôs one principle that every successful organization seems to agree on: great organizations are made up of great people. No amount of organizational design can make up for people who lack the skills, ambition, and passion to accomplish great things. One of the most triumphant passages of Valve‚Äôs [employee handbook](https://steamcdn-a.akamaihd.net/apps/valve/Valve_NewEmployeeHandbook.pdf) reads:

> You have the power to green-light projects. You have the power to ship products. A flat structure removes every organizational barrier between your work and the customer enjoying that work.
>
> If you‚Äôre thinking to yourself, ‚ÄúWow, that sounds like a lot of responsibility,‚Äù you‚Äôre right. And that‚Äôs why hiring is the single most important thing you will ever do at Valve. Any time you interview a potential hire, you need to ask yourself not only if they‚Äôre talented or collaborative but also if they‚Äôre capable of literally running this company, because they will be.

![Diagram from the Valve employee handbook](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/7s3GxOem2Zf5JQaQXyJDH.png)

Diagram from the Valve employee handbook

As far as I can tell, ‚Äúengage amazing humans‚Äù is the core strategy of all great organizations, and especially those that aspire to high levels of decentralization. Organizations are made up of people, so if you want to build great things, it‚Äôs natural that the first rule is to work with great people.

Working with great people makes your life easier. Great people are smarter and more competent than you at the things they spend time on. They see around corners you didn‚Äôt know existed. They deliver excellence in ambiguous situations without guidance. They have strong vibes and attract each other with these vibes.

Companies like Valve and Amazon, elite military units like the US Marines, and co-living environments like intentional communities all draw boundaries around themselves and carefully evaluate who they let in. By constantly attempting to raise the bar, they can keep scaling without the need for more structure and rules. From Valve again:

> We believe that if we‚Äôre careful, it will work better and better the larger we get. This might seem counterintuitive, but it‚Äôs a direct consequence of hiring great, accomplished, capable people. Getting this to work right is a tricky proposition, though, and depends highly on our continued vigilance in recruiting/hiring. **If we start adding people to the company who aren‚Äôt as capable as we are at operating as high-powered, self-directed, senior decision makers, then lots of the stuff discussed in this book will stop working.**

DAOs often attempt to be permissionless, allowing anyone to join the community. Maintaining openness, permeability, and an inclusive approach to newcomers allows DAOs to [grow quickly](https://creators.mirror.xyz/0OIn4KF6tGdygbA979gRxWitZ-wKuukkqzrf1Xq9xME), [increase diversity](https://creators.mirror.xyz/Y72O0H9QX0GRgy6AXrTflaGSuTQcEQ86OxZWutfp9ao), and [progressively decentralize](https://a16z.com/2020/01/09/progressive-decentralization-crypto-product-management/). But there‚Äôs a clear tension between bringing in the best people and maintaining an open and accessible community:

![Quality of contributions, autonomy of contributors, and permeability of the organization‚Äîpick two](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/eIJHAj6V7HvBNbhhSL0G-.png)

Quality of contributions, autonomy of contributors, and permeability of the organization‚Äîpick two

I think the best solution we have to solve for this balance is contributor proof-of-work. Proof-of-work, in this context, refers to the ability for new community members to demonstrate their capabilities and increase the scope of their work as they build trust within the community. By creating [systems for self-organizing teams to publicly accomplish the organization‚Äôs goals](https://snapshot.org/#/cabindao.eth/proposal/0xe7cc4dbdfe3c8e5ed9ef9607078d344d45a3dd65593a230916491f5f17fe7f95), DAOs can build feedback loops for strong contributors to succeed and positively reinforce the organization's culture, capabilities, and scalability.

### 2 - Help members self-organize

Once you are surrounded by great people, you can work together to build systems for effective collective action. In order to self-organize, people need:

1. Clearly defined missions
2. Small groups executing at the edges
3. Information accessibility
4. Minimum viable self-governance

**Clearly defined missions**

Like a [slime mold](https://komoroske.com/slime-mold/) growing towards an available source of food or an [oak tree](https://twitter.com/JonathanHillis/status/1519763362225311744) growing towards sunlight, the first thing self-organizing systems need is a goal to grow towards.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/IxhN96MB5t1rponeflVj3.png)

Jim Mattis, a US Marine who served as Secretary of Defense, helped define the US military‚Äôs [counterinsurgency (COIN) doctrine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Counterinsurgency). COIN is an approach to warfare designed to react to highly decentralized terrorist networks. This decentralized military doctrine considers clearly defined missions to be the most important prerequisite for allowing groups to self-organize, because no one can coordinate without a shared understanding of the goal. From Mattis‚Äô memoir, [Call Sign Chaos](https://www.amazon.com/Call-Sign-Chaos-Learning-Lead/dp/0812996836):

> The correct exercise of independent action requires a common understanding of both the mission and intent of what the mission is expected to accomplish.

This is why the most successful DAOs so far are [organized around strong memes](https://creators.mirror.xyz/5YUK1Ef3BEMA9QEZvbOIh7ukbjAYL_0cs_NLplqgHw4) that give members a shared sense of purpose and mission. At Cabin, we are experimenting with a [city council that defines objectives for each season and creates budget allocation for those objectives](https://snapshot.org/#/cabindao.eth/proposal/0xe7cc4dbdfe3c8e5ed9ef9607078d344d45a3dd65593a230916491f5f17fe7f95).

**Small groups executing at the edges**

Once participants have a sense of the mission, they can get together in groups and attempt to accomplish it. Successful groups tend to be small and purposeful. More people does not usually result in better outcomes, because coordination costs increase geometrically. This coordination cost is the flip side to [Metcalfe‚Äôs Law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metcalfe%27s_law):

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/b87P126tgPueOLfs9V6rO.png)

If you [ask people what group sizes they like working with](https://twitter.com/JonathanHillis/status/1510604165894094870), they will generally tell you numbers between 2 and 12 people. Amazon is well known for popularizing the term [two pizza team](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/whitepapers/latest/introduction-devops-aws/two-pizza-teams.html) to describe this concept (though at Cabin, we prefer [one sauna teams](https://twitter.com/JonathanHillis/status/1518266694736781315?s=20&t=caro5eSVCq_kRRsENnF_-Q)). DAOs can be thought of as constellations of these small teams, sometimes called pods, squads, guilds, or‚Äîif you want bad lore‚ÄîsubDAOs.

**Information accessibility**

Allowing people to self-organize into small teams requires them to have access to information and the ability to execute autonomously. Information access may be the most underestimated benefit of DAOs. Blockchains, by nature, are public ledgers. This means that DAOs, by nature, operate with high degrees of transparency about resource allocation. This is a particularly important breakthrough for DAOs because information transparency and accessibility, especially for newcomers, is a weakness of decentralized organizations like Valve:

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/LkaAnur3yW7lzaERR6iLU.png)

Companies end up developing implicit hierarchies of information availability, even if no formal hierarchies exist. Knowledge, as they say, is power. If conversations, transactions, and processes are publicly available, anyone can (at least in theory) enter the organization and contribute positively to it.

**Minimum viable self-governance**

Autonomy means individuals can make execution decisions without bureaucratic processes that constrain their decision-making authority. The problem with rules or processes is that they can be captured by special interests who use them to retain power instead of for the common good. An example of this is the [United States House Rules and Manual](https://www.govinfo.gov/app/collection/hman/117/04), which contains hundreds of pages of drivel like this:

> A reappropriation of unexpended balances of appropriations may not be reported in a general appropriation bill, and may not be in order as an amendment thereto‚Ä¶

Rules beget more rules, followed by processes to make sure rules are followed. Rules that determine available actions are inherently political tools. Before long, the meta-game of rule making becomes the primary force for executing the will of power, regardless of how useful the outcomes of this process are. This was one of the primary fears of the US founding fathers in designing a system of governance.

But rules exist for a reason. Resources are constrained, and if anyone can do anything with collective resources, they are quickly diminished in a [tragedy of the commons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tragedy_of_the_commons). What is needed to solve this problem is minimum viable self-governance. Elinor Ostrom‚Äôs [design principles for common pool resource institutions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elinor_Ostrom#Design_principles_for_Common_Pool_Resource_(CPR)_institution) is the leading framework for how humans have solved this problem in a bottom-up way for millennia.

More recent thinking on [lorecraft](https://studio.ribbonfarm.com/p/on-lore?s=r) is an interesting reframing of the rules problem. By focusing on memetic tools for building cultural stories, lore is a compelling alternative to rules-based systems. Telling stories about cultural norms is a [powerful narrative tool for organizing without adding process](https://studio.ribbonfarm.com/p/lands-of-lorecraft?s=r).

### 3 - Empower mission-driven leaders

There‚Äôs no such thing as a leaderless organization. When you try to build perfectly flat organizations, you just end up hiding hierarchy in illegible ways, [which seems to be an issue at Valve](https://medium.com/dunia-media/the-nightmare-of-valves-self-organizing-utopia-6d32d329ecdb). While transparent and accessible information can help combat this, the most illegible hierarchies form when groups pretend they don‚Äôt exist.

When we say [mission-driven leaders](https://creators.mirror.xyz/BIKmTKdNiMkK1dbtUInS0zoZgVdo18i55Vh3iMU9g_I), we mean it in two ways. First, it means that the best leaders are missionaries, not mercenaries. They believe in and are dedicated to the greater mission of the organization. Second, it means that leadership is a temporary, transient role designed to solve for a specific mission.

DAOs offer a unique solution to this problem that hasn‚Äôt been technically feasible before: put direct executive power in the hands of all individuals in an organization. In his [anti-capture framework](https://spengrah.mirror.xyz/f6bZ6cPxJpP-4K_NB7JcjbU0XblJcaf7kVLD75dOYRQ), Spencer Graham identifies direct executive power as the key to successful decentralized organizations:

> Separation between decision-making and executive power is uniquely possible within capture-resistant structures. It is why decentralized decision-making is not a strict requirement. It is also why decentralized organizations can be fluid and adaptable. When executive power is decentralized, leadership can truly emerge from anywhere.

Humans want and need leaders to create shelling points for collective action. DAOs should be _leaderful_ organizations ‚Äî groups that support just-in-time leadership from a wide range of capable individuals. A leader is whoever knows what to do next. Effective DAOs give members the tools to execute when they are the best leader for a shared cause.

While Amazon is well known for their use of two-pizza teams, what‚Äôs less well known is that this type of leadership‚Äì‚Äìknown internally as [single threaded owners](https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/enterprise-strategy/two-pizza-teams-are-just-the-start-accountability-and-empowerment-are-key-to-high-performing-agile-organizations-part-2/)‚Äì‚Äìis considered even more important for team cohesion and success. This type of fluid leadership only works if people within the organization have a strong bias towards action. The organization must be designed to support people taking the initiative to step into self-defined leadership roles and making things happen.

### 4 - Have a bias towards action

The CIA wrote a fascinating manual called the [Simple Sabotage Field Manual](https://www.hsdl.org/?abstract&did=750070). In addition to detailed tips and tricks for starting fires, targeting warehouses, destroying tools, and clogging toilets, the manual includes an entire section on undermining the work of organizations. The manual describes the failure state of organizations that have unclear leadership and a lack of bias towards action:

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/5y4185aUkjJVcaKg_f659.png)

Anyone who has ever been in an organization attempting too much flatness and consensus has probably experienced these problems. This was the downfall of intentional living communes of the 60s and larger experiments in communism through the 1990s. When everyone has an equal voice in everything all of the time, groups end up talking a lot and accomplishing nothing.

One antidote to this problem comes from co-living communities, which are often organized around a principle called [do-ocracy](https://communitywiki.org/wiki/DoOcracy). This principle states that, generally, whoever actually does the thing makes the rules. Phil Levin, one of Cabin‚Äôs city council members and founder of several successful co-living communities, put together a fantastic presentation called _[What DAOs can learn from co-living communities](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1_fgNg-rXrk3Q-18Tvmnj2VV6D8qcSIfHiFrlyoo6_Yw/edit#slide=id.ga247f2dd33_0_145)_. The communities Phil has started thrive on the principle of self-appointed do-ocratic leadership:

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/WpoVncZ1IE-UyYgUdCbfC.png)

The goal is to minimize governance and consensus decision-making by empowering individuals to make autonomous actions as long as they are reversible and inexpensive. Another good example of this type of decentralized leadership comes from Cabin‚Äôs Build Weeks.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/DuIW7EKJVpPBnfrM1sM5J.png)

[Build Weeks are self-organized](https://creators.mirror.xyz/Oe86T6-4COpnuw5QV09G_82jdshQaRn4z-Rz9k_cfx8) by a primary build leader, and also support room for other builders to go on do-ocratic side quests that contribute to the built environment of Cabin‚Äôs Neighborhood Zero. Here‚Äôs how participants in a recent Build Week described effective do-ocracy:

> Despite a lack of stringent roles and duties, everything got done, we were able to use our unique skills and interests without any conflict, and most importantly, everyone got to drive the skidsteer.

Valve also emphasizes a do-ocratic approach to product development, where anyone can ‚Äúcome up with a bright idea, tell a coworker about it, work on it together, and ship it‚Äù:

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/1ctftuqBgcObZl_EP5vrh.png)

To make this work, you need to design your organizational processes to explicitly reward people trying new things. As Jim Mattis explains:

> Instillation of personal initiative and risk taking doesn't spring forward spontaneously. It must be cultivated and rewarded in an organization's culture \[‚Ä¶\] Be tolerant of mistakes. If risk takers are punished, then you will retain only the risk averse.

When things don‚Äôt go well, ask yourself: is it because someone took strong initiative and the experiment failed, or because they failed to take the initiative in the first place?

### 5 - Play infinite games

Rewarding leaders with a bias towards action is key to successfully executing as a decentralized organization. But execution is a finite game‚Äîa convergent action to accomplish a specific goal. The final principle of effective decentralized organizations is inherently divergent: play [infinite games](https://www.amazon.com/Finite-Infinite-Games-James-Carse/dp/1476731713).

Vibes, reciprocity, and trust are infinite games. They are not played to win, but to keep playing. Infinite games are played for intrinsic rewards:

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/vRRn1wUriscP1h1DCxp1p.png)

The co-living communities Phil has helped start revolve around the principle of intrinsic rewards. Phil‚Äôs partner Kristen, a behavioral scientist, knew that intrinsic rewards are a much more powerful and fulfilling form of motivation than extrinsic ones. As a result, their co-living communities do not offer direct compensation for essentially any work within the community. This policy has ultimately made the community stronger and more productive than if everyone played finite games of resource allocation.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/9XbA1L4MzYhgYiLT1viOb.png)

Intrinsic community building means valuing community members beyond the work they do for the organization and allowing people to contribute to the community without expecting extrinsic rewards. While the work of a DAO should reward excellent executors with increased responsibility and financial upside, the whole community does not need to be held to the same standard because the motivations for participation are different. Communities are about vibes and relationships ‚Äî both of which are driven by intrinsic motivation and infinite games.

Infinite games will take DAOs to interesting places. Amazon is playing an infinite game. Notice what‚Äôs missing from Amazon‚Äôs famous flywheel‚Äîany arrows leaving the diagram:

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/cTlIsRyuq1W3X9aIfXn2S.png)

Amazon is one of the world‚Äôs most powerful self-perpetuating economic feedback loops. It is a mechanism for feeding back on its own growth, which creates exponential growth in revenue without capturing profits:

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/5YxIY8ce-E5-0q0BEuhrK.png)

The most potent DAOs will follow a similar path‚Äîthey will create intrinsically motivated [communities that self-perpetuate memes and culture](https://creators.mirror.xyz/5YUK1Ef3BEMA9QEZvbOIh7ukbjAYL_0cs_NLplqgHw4) while simultaneously developing protocol [hyperstructures](https://jacob.energy/hyperstructures.html) that live indefinitely and create value without necessarily extracting profits.

This is the end state of sufficiently decentralized organizations that points us towards a future that companies are not designed to produce. Organizations of the future can be collectively owned and organized around a token that provides utility to those who hold or stake it and that never attempts to produce dividends or profits that are extracted from the system‚Äîall while still providing massive value to network participants. Like ecosystems, economies, and other forms of complex adaptive systems, DAOs can be structures for playing infinite self‚Äìfulfilling games that reward participants with meaning and purpose.

## The DAO playbook

No two DAOs will be able to follow the exact same playbook, because their purposes, communities, and resources will look different. But, like companies, a diversity of products, business models, and cultures will develop in DAOs‚Äîand there will be repeatable patterns of success in the ways organizations treat DAO as a verb.

Ultimately, by integrating the ways that [centralized hierarchies create efficiency and decentralized networks create resilience](https://superbenefit.mirror.xyz/unisNGUtHyRF7Zcp9CBbC-VhICOvVm0uzTFJUPX-Icg), we can chart a path towards more effective organizations. Charting this path will require a deep understanding of historical precedent and a penchant for constant experimentation. No matter what these organizations of the future end up looking like, the ones that succeed will probably do these things:

1. Recruit the best people
2. Help members self-organize
3. Empower mission-driven leaders
4. Have a bias towards action
5. Play infinite games

* * *

rafa, Cabin

October 21st, 2021

_Welcome to the third deep dive on how we are building [Cabin](https://twitter.com/creatorcabins). We‚Äôve aggregated everything we know about reward design from discussions with multiple DAOs, and combined that with information about compensation in traditional businesses._

_As a DAO contributor, you can use this guide to help understand what options you have. As a DAO community engineer, you can use this document to design general guidance for your community. **There‚Äôs also benchmarks in the Appendix.**_

_This article is for regular contributors and community engineers / builders. If you are just starting your DAO journey, [take a peek over here instead!](https://creators.mirror.xyz/862A5rBtKX3BC8eEircDnGwPIJJTJ33hn-MvnukByPc)_

* * *

## It‚Äôs all incentives? Always has been.

> _Bobby logged into the server. Today the contributors had an important discussion pending: bounties and contributor rewards. As part of the conversation, Bobby had to help reach consensus on benchmark bounty rewards and a proposal for ongoing payments for regular contributors (incl. part-time and full-time). However, Bobby wasn't sure how to go about this - What were other communities doing? What incentives should they use to support their overall mission? Should the community allocate tokens or USDC?_

Twitter Embed

Not found

There‚Äôs a Bobby in every DAO, striving to help make contributor rewards _**transparent**_, _**decentralized**_, _**fair**_, and _**sustainable**_. After all, incentives run the world and can make or break an organization.

That being said, these are very early days. A variety of new rewards will likely emerge over the next few years - just like NFT status symbols were popularized last summer. **This reward recipe book should be considered intermediary guidance** while we discover new rewards inspired by game design, and incorporating novel ownership mechanisms.

> _üí° Quick Note: We will exclude token appreciation, community-wide disbursements (e.g. airdrops) and reputation in this article. We will likely take a look at these topics in other articles related to community engagement design._

## Recipes not Instructions

It can be tempting as a community genesis member or guild veteran to try and define a clear set of instructions. Creating static company-wide policies is how most of us have done it in traditional organizations. It‚Äôs like a warm weighted blanket - a feeling of comfort in certainty.

As a result of this dynamic space, it‚Äôs probably best to think about community guidance as contextual (artistic!) recipes while encouraging individual members and guilds to find the right solutions for their context.

## What is a ‚ÄúReward‚Äù anyways?

Rewards can mean a variety of different things.

At Cabin, when we use the term Reward, we mean "pay for eligible work". When we mention ‚Äúpay‚Äù, we mean rewards in the form of liquid ownership. In other words, rewards should:

1. **Liquid**: Be useful for rent and food
2. **Ownership**: Distribute governance power of the community

The latter is critical, as without it we run the risk of developing negative aspects of the [gig economy.](https://qz.com/1556194/the-gig-economy-is-quietly-undermining-a-century-of-worker-protections/)

At at a top level, we believe a good reward recipe book covers the following steps:

1. Reward Principles: What‚Äôs the north star?
2. Reward Eligibility: Who should we reward?
3. Reward Structure: What should we reward, under what terms?
4. Reward Amount: How much should we reward?
5. Reward Consensus: How do we agree on the reward?

![Five steps to explore reward options for yourself and your community](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/BWA1xUO9sMhj1FexPz3L9.png)

Five steps to explore reward options for yourself and your community

## STEP 1 - Reward Principles: What‚Äôs the north star?

There are a lot of options in terms of who could get rewarded, what to reward, and how to distribute rewards. Spending some time thinking about decision-making guardrails can help narrow down the design space. In HR-speak, these are usually called ‚ÄúDesign Principles‚Äù and ‚ÄúDesign Practices‚Äù.

Here‚Äôs an example from Warcamp (DAOHaus):

![Source: Contributor Compensation Revamp Proposal, DAOhaus Core Contributors](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/wlFILCY7FmDqV_G431d4D.PNG)

Source: Contributor Compensation Revamp Proposal, DAOhaus Core Contributors

**Design Principles** should definitely vary across communities and over time. Over time, they reflect changes in membership, and most importantly, the evolution of the mission and focus. Some examples include:

- Consistency, Flexibility, Collaboration, Alignment, Transparency, Simplicity, Ownership, Sustainability, Fairness, Decentralization, Predictability, Efficiency, Automation.

Optimizing for one principle can mean decreasing focus on others. However, this doesn‚Äôt have to be the case given all the new technology we have at our disposal.

Twitter Embed

In addition to choosing basic principles, it‚Äôs useful to define **Design Practices**. This is the translation of principles into expected operational actions. Here are a few examples that help with the design process:

1. **We will design rewards with inclusive collaboration as a core value:** This means testing rewards for accessibility, diversity, teamwork, and mutual generosity.
2. **We will review rewards regularly:** For new DAOs this might be weekly or monthly. For more mature DAOs a Seasonal review probably is more appropriate.
3. **We will keep it simple:** Making reward recommendations easily understandable by contributors helps them focus on what the DAO needs. Complex rewards lead to ‚Äúhacks‚Äù (e.g. like tip farming)
1. Example: Create guidance via ‚ÄúReward Personas'' and ‚ÄúWork Categories‚Äù. These can be used as a reference and tweaked based on specific context.
4. **We will calibrate rewards to a target monthly and yearly take-home:** Make sure it meets expectations (i.e. higher than minimum wage, covers your cost of living).

## STEP 2 - Reward Eligibility: Who should we reward?

Prior to determining what reward to give and how to distribute it, it's often good to ask: _**Who should we reward?**_ At Cabin we will call this Eligibility.

> _üí° Quick Note: In a traditional business setting, a full-time employee performs full-time work. Full-time work is Eligible for compensation, which could be an hourly wage, monthly salary and a certain variable payment (e.g. bonus)._

Reward eligibility is based on **(1) the work itself** and **(2) the individual** (via role or contribution level) **.** Here's a simple way to determine whether or not a piece of work should be rewarded in the first place.

Our initial Cabin guidance is below. We recommend each DAO review and create a custom map based on their mission, treasury plan, and community needs.

![Sample Work Eligibility Worksheet](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/vhPZXGA6g7WJ3xUCfuZnw.png)

Sample Work Eligibility Worksheet

As the worksheet suggests, Cabin is currently rewarding creation, but not ideation. **We want to incentivize completion.** In the future, if we run out of ideas, we might revisit and reassign rewards to incentivize proposals.

In some cases, community members may not have structured work assignments but should be rewarded based on continued participation:

![Sample Member Eligibility Worksheet](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/jJRFM25nkPBqUHJtHRXIn.png)

Sample Member Eligibility Worksheet

It can be a useful exercise to create mnemonic devices to communicate these more complex frameworks. Mnemonic devices include memes, sayings, or other word-play like an acrostic. At Cabin we don‚Äôt have one yet, but it will likely pop-up soon enough.

> _üí° Quick Note: These are examples of eligibility and are not mutually exclusive or collectively exhaustive. Many new creative eligibility criteria can be considered, especially related to inter-related characteristics. For example, we are certain that special eligibility will include future reputation protocols, transaction history, mutual referrals, and staking status._

## STEP 3 - Reward Structure: What should we reward, under what terms?

Once you‚Äôve decided on which work types and member groups are rewarded, the next step is to create a map of **reward types and terms**. Here‚Äôs what Cabin might use over the next few seasons (still TBD):

![Reward Types Sample Worksheet](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/iSoeFhQZBr67-FJ4OTOWt.png)

Reward Types Sample Worksheet

![Reward Terms Sample Worksheet](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/ULIWncVcTRGQ08iBUZr2a.png)

Reward Terms Sample Worksheet

**Any community member should be able to review the reward mechanisms and request the ones that best fit** their risk profile, short-term and long-term preferences, and the work they are completing.

A DAO can create Reward Personas to show community members examples of how their work will be rewarded.

```
Reward Persona Example:

* Contributor: New Member, Writer, Bounty-Hunter

* Work: Completing an deep-dive research write-up for DAO

* Reward Eligibility: Yes (eligible based on project)

* Reward Type: Pay 50-50 CABIN-USDC (Asset) per project (Allocation) from Treasury (Source).

* Reward Terms: Paid immediately (Timing), scaled based on complexity (Multiplier), once upon completion (Disbursement).
```

## STEP 4 - Reward Amount: How much should we reward?

It‚Äôs typically easier to determine eligibility and reward type / terms before determining the size of the reward.

In the previous example, the writer agreed:

- (Eligibility) that they should be paid
- (Type) what the reward should include
- (Terms) how they should be given the reward

The final decision (and usually hardest!) is to agree on the amount.

Reward amounts are currently calculated either by individual decision, algorithm, or a combination of both.

We won‚Äôt be covering algorithmic allocations in this article - as there are other experts, and we‚Äôre probably best to leave that to them (e.g. like Coordinape).

For individually calculated rewards, consider market pay rates (if any available), total effort worked, and adjustment values based on volatility and upside. Here‚Äôs an example of reward formula design:

### Scenario 1: Formula for Base Payouts, Bounties, or Projects

```
Reward Amount =
(Market Price USDC * digital asset conversion rate * Multiplier * Volatility Risk Adjustment)¬†/ Upside Opportunity
```

Variable Definitions:

- **Market Price:** Wages for comparable web2 job (e.g. using glassdoor, or other benchmark like web2 salary midpoint)
- **Conversion Rate:** USD to Token price conversion, could be defined as spot price on day of payment or 30-day average.
- **Multiplier:** Increased payout based on internal demand, work complexity, effort level (could be between a 1-3x adjustment)
- **Volatility Risk:** Increased payout based on liquidity availability, DAO maturity, market sentiment, recent digital asset volatility (e.g. usually a 1-3x adjustment)
- **Upside Opportunity:** Decreased payout based on expected growth. Note this should be carefully considered since forecasting increased valuations is likely inaccurate.

At Cabin we pay more than standard market rates where possible because we‚Äôre in a high risk environment. If your token payouts have high volatility, the pay should be much higher than a FAANG basic salary.

> üí° _For more information about designing custom formulas and indexes, you can read about how these are used in Materials Engineering and Design [here](http://mech.vub.ac.be/teaching/info/Ontwerpmethodologie/Appendix%20les%203%20Materiaal%20Indices.pdf)._

### Scenario 2: KPI-Driven Payouts

In more advanced cases, payouts are tied to work outcomes, likerevenue sharing agreements on a specific product development process, for example.¬† Most often, KPI targets through commission or defined as a curve, trigger a reward. Here are some examples:

- **Set Targets:** If average time on the website increases from 30 sec to 45 sec, then provide payment of X tokens.
- **Commission**: At Cabin we sell weekly passports for IRL gatherings of guilds and DAOs. If a member successfully sells one of the passports, they receive 10% of the value.
- **Payout Curves:** Inspired by the pay ranges of traditional sales teams, a DAO could pay out X tokens at 100% of goal but a 200% payout at 150% of goal. You can read more about these types of models [here](https://aurochssolutions.com/blog/different-types-of-sales-incentive-payout-curves-explained/).

## STEP 5 - Reward Consensus: How do we agree on the reward?

A selected team of community leads, mediators, or stewards or a larger community vote can help a final rewards proposal reach consensus.

Either way, the DAO has to put safeguards to protect the treasury.¬† For example, a community can cap treasury disbursement based on available funds, or allocate some of the treasury to use for rewards during the upcoming season.

1. **Selected Team Consensus:** A few selected people are given permission to approve rewards. For example, a specified community member, identified as the Guild Lead, tells the team that the proposed reward is either in line with the plan or not.
2. **Community Consensus:** Community members vote via Tally or Snapshot to approve the reward proposal. This is typically used when agreeing on (1) recurring payments to part-time or full-time contributors, or (2) retroactively awarding contributions (e.g. via Coordinape).

## Reward Bias Awareness

In designing new reward systems, we should keep expected biases in mind. DAOs should work together, create a new metadata framework, and build a public database of payments. Over time, anyone can look at this to help inform their pay requests, identify new types of bias, confirm offers, and serve as a reference for other DAOs.

Twitter Embed

Not found

Over the past few months there have been three types of digital bias emerging:

1. **Network** (Geography, Gender, etc.)
2. **Inheritance** (OG, Founder preference)
3. **Assets** (PFP, Digital Inventory)

These biases sow discord (pun intended!) within a community and create unhealthy power dynamics.

For example, if a new member with a premium PFP joins a community and gets a higher payment for similar work and similar value, other contributors will claim back-payments, develop resentment towards the individual, and potentially actively block the work.

This said, we need to¬† differentiate between rewards bias and reward tinkering based on new needs. _**By creating a public database and an extensive (but automated!) meta-data framework, we uncover these trends and take steps to prevent bias. In the meantime, each community will have to invest in local bias awareness.**_

## Better Rewards, Better Collaboration

Rewards are a foundational aspect to any community and will be a topic to revisit, debate, and experiment with openly. We look forward to seeing how DAOs evolve and what new products emerge. After all, clear and competitive reward expectations will be one of the pieces that will accelerate the mass migration of workers from web2 to web3.

Cabin Launches the First Network¬†City

![0x522C6b0Aa5A14E1771Aab5646247349fFa9E5111](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Bcuo3ZN1NxnWnCCtmG4Pg.jpeg?height=400&width=400)

Cabin

0x522C

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/C-xaKqE85LzBuqP8AwCUo.jpg?height=1849&width=2177)

Jackson Steger

May 23rd, 2023

Mint

Over the last two years, the Cabin community has come together across dozens of IRL activations and hundreds of online events to begin developing a global network of nature-immersed properties designed for thoughtful creators and remote workers.

We have built neighborhoods, rehabilitated orchards, designed tiny cabins, assembled saunas, housed creators, interviewed city builders, hosted dinner parties, played games, facilitated meaningful coliving, and gathered thoughtfully to make new friends and reimagine how we live.

Today, on the eve of our second birthday, Cabin is launching the [world‚Äôs first network city](http://cabin.city/). A network city is a set of globally distributed neighborhoods that have a shared culture, economy, and system of governance.

## Creating a network city of beautiful neighborhoods

Cabin neighborhoods are designed to cater to remote workers and creators who love nature. Our network city is made up of 20 coliving neighborhoods and outposts around the world, including the following locations:

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/HCehXERUujmBYpLpm78Yb.png)

Each neighborhood shares three characteristics:

1. **Access to beautiful nature:** Breathtaking scenery available outside the front door.

2. **Fast internet:** Reliable, high-speed WiFi to make it easy to connect and do work.

3. **Strong community:** Good vibes for thoughtful people to live together smoothly.


The flavor of each individual neighborhood changes from place-to-place; that‚Äôs what makes them fun to explore! But no matter where they are, all Cabin neighborhoods provide a great balance of work, community, and nature.

To browse these neighborhoods, meet other members, and otherwise navigate Cabin‚Äôs network city, check out the [Network City Center](http://cabin.city/), which includes:

![View our integrated suite of applications at cabin.city](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/ojJAlJzzberrcOWMnTWQk.png)

View our integrated suite of applications at cabin.city

- **Cabin Citizenship:** a subscription membership for remote workers to live in our network city.

- **City Directory:** an online registry of our city‚Äôs beautiful coliving neighborhoods in nature.

- **Cabin Census:** a community directory where members can build identity and reputation.

- **Town Hall:** a discord server where our community gathers to make plans and memes.


These products work in concert to help citizens colive, create, and conserve together across the world.

## Cabin Citizenship

Traditionally, citizenship implies rights, access, and responsibilities in civic, political, and social life. Being a Cabin Citizen is characterized by a similar set of benefits and responsibilities.

Cabin Citizenship is a subscription membership to Cabin‚Äôs network city. To become a Cabin Citizen, you must get vouched for by an existing Citizen. Once you receive a vouch, you can mint a Citizenship by paying 0.2 ETH annually (As of this writing, 0.2 ETH is about $360). We accept credit card or crypto payment.

Citizenship is free if you attend a Build Week at a Cabin neighborhood or hold 1,000 ‚Ç°ABIN.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/gE5LUQBxRCyvqfNibc9ly.png)

### What‚Äôs included in Citizenship

Citizens are issued digital and physical passports that give them access to our community‚Äôs global network of properties, experiences, and members:

**üåÜACCESS OUR NETWORK CITY**

- **Explore Cabin‚Äôs neighborhoods:** exclusive access to coliving and residencies at Cabin neighborhoods around the world.

- **Create listings in the City Directory:** list your own offerings in the City Directory and connect with other Citizens at your property.

- **Join Citizen-only events:** exclusive access to Cabin-organized events, including‚Ä¶
  - an invitation to _Cabin Camp_, our annual Citizen gathering at a 500-person summer camp, complete with a water park, a lake, an archery range, and programming designed to further connect our Citizens and help grow our network city. The first Cabin Camp will take place in October 2024.

  - a cosmic celebration of the April 2024 solar eclipse, on the path of totality at Cabin‚Äôs Neighborhood Zero.

üó≥Ô∏è **GOVERN OUR NETWORK CITY**

- **Receive 25 ‚Ç°ABIN:** each of the first 5,040 Founding Citizens will receive ‚Ç°ABIN to participate in transparent on-chain governance of our network city.

- **Receive a numbered Founding Citizen NFT:** to commemorate and digitally verify your Citizenship across the [Network City Center](http://cabin.city/).

- **Vouch for other Citizens:** each Citizen can vouch for up to five new Cabin Citizens per year.


‚úÖ¬†**GET CITIZENSHIP PERKS**

- **Special merch:** access to Citizen-only Cabin merch drops - beginning with the ‚ÄúWelcome Home‚Äù drop available [here](https://cabingeneralstore.myshopify.com/).

- **Access to a Citizens-only channel:** join the #founding-citizens channel in our Town Hall for early access to features and the ability to impact the roadmap.

- **Thousands of dollars in partnership benefits:** discounts with vibe-aligned brands like SafetyWing, Hipcamp, and more.


### Founding Citizens

In order to plant the seeds of a strong culture, we have distributed the first Cabin Citizenships for free to original community members as a token of appreciation:

- Participants in the original donation crowdfund (101)

- Holders of at least 1,000 ‚Ç°ABIN (53)

- Passport holders (144)

- Inaugural City Directory listings (20)


This group will become the founding polis for deciding all future citizens. While we want Cabin to grow, we don‚Äôt want to grow it too fast. Vibes don‚Äôt blitzscale. By starting with this strong community of initial citizens and giving the power of community growth to you, we can increase the number of citizens without compromising the integrity and intimacy of our IRL experiences.

## Cabin‚Äôs City Directory

Cabin‚Äôs [City Directory](http://cabin.city/) is where Citizens explore neighborhoods and outposts in Cabin‚Äôs network. Citizens receive exclusive access to coliving and residencies in the City Directory and collectively curate the list of neighborhoods that make up the network city.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/jEsteKzQ9C6Ik46CL603N.png)

Cabin Citizens can add new **outposts** to the City Directory. Community members use ‚Ç°ABIN to upvote and govern which outposts become **neighborhoods**. When outposts with at least 4 bedrooms and 20 mbps internet receive 1,000 ‚Ç° in votes, they officially become a neighborhood in our network city.

The best listings in the City Directory will rise to the top of this simple [token-curated registry](https://medium.com/@tokencuratedregistry/the-token-curated-registry-whitepaper-bd2fb29299d6). This bottoms-up cultural curation ensures longterm community alignment with Cabin‚Äôs vision of a network of nature-immersed neighborhoods.

## Census

The first step to becoming a Cabin Citizen is to create a profile on **[Cabin‚Äôs Census](http://cabin.city/)**.

Anyone can create a profile in the Census and begin building their reputation and identity within the community. When you participate in our online and offline gatherings, you can earn roles, passport stamps, and tokens that give you privileges, reputation, and governance rights.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/F2vQYHPW3Jn5cvB02hnPd.png)

This credentialing system contextualizes your experience within the Cabin ecosystem and is viewable by other community members as an on-chain reputation and identity-management system.

Together, the Census, Citizenship, and the City Directory serve as the community sensemaking and coordination layer for our network city, allowing Citizens and neighborhoods to find like-minded community members, build reputation, and assemble resources.

## Reimagining How We Live

We believe that a network city is the best way to enable Citizens to live surrounded by other kind, thoughtful, creative, open-minded, playful, generous people. We are a mix of creators, builders, naturalists, gatherers, caretakers, entrepreneurs, thinkers, and doers.

If we are responsible Citizens who add new Citizens and govern our treasury thoughtfully, we will be able to offer more affordable, higher quality, and flexible housing options than are available in traditional cities. Designing community living with immediate access to nature offers unparalleled quality for the price. By offering a continuous a la carte menu of coliving and work-stay exchanges across a network of neighborhoods, we can re-write the rules for how we coordinate, connect, and live with each other.

**You can join us on this journey by visiting [cabin.city](http://cabin.city/) today.** For more on Cabin‚Äôs broader vision and strategy, check out our recently published [Vision Paper.](https://creators.mirror.xyz/zHox-AfvHbX0Q2JxAbcfwiAmOXRy7BzYafhZNlvHnmM)

A feminist financial imagination is a solutions-oriented mindset that facilitates the formation of new ideas, visioning of alternate futures, and uncovering of possibilities that would ensure the power and tools of financial systems are channeled toward advancing gender equality and justice in transformative ways. Our latest publication, ‚ÄúFostering a Feminist Financial Imagination: A Radical Conversation about Finance, Feminist Futures, and Transformative Change,‚Äù explores this concept in depth, offering strategies and recommendations for how to foster a feminist financial imagination and bring new possibilities to life. The publication, supported by Wallace Global Fund, is intended primarily for investors, feminist organizations, and the foundations and donor agencies that support them. ¬† Drawing on examples of initiatives already underway at the intersection of feminism and finance, this publication provides guidance on how the power of finance can be leveraged to create feminist, just, and human rights-based solutions to current global challenges.

# Upcoming Events

This is a big one.

After a couple weeks of holidays and seminars, we‚Äôre back next week with a _stacked_ slate of workshops and other learning experiences.

We hope learners and alumni alike will make some time next week to join-in and connect and learn before many of us again take time to be with friends and family.

## Workshops
